==Results== ===Overall results=== {{2017 Turkish constitutional referendum results}} ===Results by province=== {{incomplete section|date=April 2018}} {{2017 Turkish constitutional referendum provincial results}} ===Overseas results=== {{2017 Turkish constitutional referendum overseas results}} == Reactions == ===Sovereign states=== * {{flag|Austria}} – Foreign Minister [[Sebastian Kurz]] expressed his opposition to Turkey's accession to the European Union.{{cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/reactions-turkey-urged-to-heal-divisions-after-poll/|title=Reactions: Turkey urged to heal divisions after poll|publisher=}} * {{AZE}} – President [[Ilham Aliyev]] was the first international leader to call the Turkish President, saying that the result demonstrated "the Turkish people's great support" for Erdoğan's policy.{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/turkey/world-leaders-congratulate-erdogan-on-referendum-win/798500|title=World leaders congratulate Erdoğan on referendum win|website=Anadolu Agency|access-date=2017-04-18}} * {{flag|Belarus}} – President [[Alexander Lukashenko]] congratulated Turkey on the successful referendum. * {{CHN}} – Chinese Deputy Prime Minister [[Liu Yandong]], who was visiting Turkey at the time of the referendum, congratulated Erdoğan and the Turkish people on the victory.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/erdogan-set-to-visit-china-in-may-to-join-belt-and-road-summit-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=112154&NewsCatID=510|title=Erdoğan set to visit China in May to join "Belt and Road Summit" - BUSINESS|website=Hürriyet Daily News {{!}} LEADING NEWS SOURCE FOR TURKEY AND THE REGION|access-date=2017-04-18}} * {{flag|Cyprus}} – Government spokesman Nicos Christodoulides said that Cyprus hopes Turkey's stance will move the peace talks forward toward the stated goal of reunifying the island as a federation. * {{FRA}} – President [[François Hollande]] stated that the Turkish people have the right to decide how to organize political institutions, but the referendum results show that Turkey is divided about the reforms. * {{flag|Georgia}} – Prime Minister [[Giorgi Kvirikashvili]] congratulated Turkey on the referendum results and remarked that Turkey’s stable development was important to Georgia. * {{GER}} – Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said the tight referendum result showed that Turkey is divided and reports over irregularities should be taken seriously.{{cite news|title=European Leaders Say Vote Shows 'Deeply Divided' Turkey|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2017-04-17/merkel-and-gabriel-say-respect-right-of-turks-to-decide-on-constitution}} Peter Altmaier, Merkel's chief of staff, said that Germany "would respect a result that came about in a free and democratic vote". Asked if the result was indeed free and democratic, he said he would wait for the verdict of election observers.{{cite news|title=Germany glad bitter Turkish referendum campaign over: foreign minister|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-referendum-germany-idUSKBN17I0O4}} * {{IRN}} – Iranian Foreign Minister, [[Mohammad Javad Zarif]], extended congratulations to his Turkish counterpart, [[Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2017/04/17/518421/Iran-Turkey-Mohammad-Javad-Zarif-Mevlut-Cavusoglu-referendum|title=PressTV-Zarif offers congratulations over Turkey 'Yes' vote|access-date=2017-04-18}} * {{IRQ}} – Iraqi Vice President [[Osama al-Nujaifi]] sent a message to congratulate the Turkish President. * {{KAZ}} – President [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] sent a telegram of congratulations to Erdoğan. * {{flag|Nigeria}} – President [[Muhammadu Buhari]] has congratulated the people and government of Turkey on the successful conclusion of the country’s referendum. * {{PAK}} – President [[Mamnoon Hussain]] and Prime Minister [[Nawaz Sharif]] also congratulated the Turkish people on the victory.{{cite web|url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/04/17/president-pm-congratulate-erdogan-turkish-people-on-referendum/|title=President, PM congratulate Erdoğan, Turkish people on referendum|access-date=2017-04-18}} * {{flag|Palestinian Authority}} – President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] extended congratulations to the Turkish President. * {{QAT}} – Qatar's Emir [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]] also congratulated the Turkish President on victory. * {{RUS}} – President [[Vladimir Putin]] called the Turkish President to extend congratulations on behalf of the Russian people.{{Cite news|url=http://en.trend.az/world/turkey/2743987.html|title=Putin congratulates Erdoğan on outcome of Turkey's Constitutional referendum|date=2017-04-18|work=Trend.Az|access-date=2017-04-18|language=ru-RU}} * {{SAU}} – Saudi Arabia's cabinet congratulated Erdoğan and the Turkish people on the successful referendum of constitutional amendments.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aawsat.com/theaawsat/news-middle-east/saudi-arabia/saudi-arabia-congratulates-turkey-successful-referendum-process|title=Saudi Arabia Congratulates Turkey on Successful Referendum Process - ASHARQ AL-AWSAT English|last=Al-awsat|first=Asharq|date=2017-04-18|work=ASHARQ AL-AWSAT English|access-date=2017-04-18|language=en-US}} * {{SOM}} – Somali President [[Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed|Mohamed Farmajo]] has congratulated the people and government of Turkey on the successful referendum on Turkey's future {{cite tweet|user=M_Farmaajo|author=Mohamed Farmaajo|number=853969156747735042|date=17 April 2017|title=Congrtas to H.E @RT_Erdogan and the Turkish people for leading a successful referendum on Turkey's future. @trpresidency @TC_Mogadishu}} * {{USA}} – President [[Donald Trump]] called the Turkish President to congratulate him on the victory.{{Cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/turkey/1.783894|title=Trump Called Erdoğan to Congratulate Him on Referendum Results|last=Reuters|date=2017-04-18|work=Haaretz|access-date=2017-04-18|language=en}} ===Regional organisations=== * {{EU}} – The Spokesman for European Commission President, [[Jean-Claude Juncker]], expressed concerns over allegations of irregularities in the referendum and called on Turkish civil authorities to launch transparent investigations into the claims.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/apr/18/turkey-should-investigate-referendum-vote-irregularities-says-eu-commission |title=Turkey should investigate referendum vote 'irregularities', ''Закон Яровой''), also '''Yarovaya package/bag''', refers to a pair of [[Russia]]n [[federal law|federal bills]], 374-FZ and 375-FZ, passed in 2016.http://www.garant.ru/news/782190/ The bills amend a pre-existing [[counter-terrorism]] law and separate laws regulating additional counter-terror and public safety measures. It is known to the public under the last name of one of its creators—[[Irina Yarovaya]]. Among the amendments included an expansion of authority for law enforcement agencies, new requirements for data collection and mandatory deciphering in the telecommunications industry, and increased regulation of [[evangelism]], including a ban on the performance of "missionary activities" in non-religious settings. == Legislative history == In April 2016 [[Irina Yarovaya]], together with [[Aleksey Pushkov|Aleksei Pushkov]], and Nadezhda Gerasimova and [[Federation Council (Russia)|senator]] Victor Ozerov introduced a project of legislation that would toughen penalties for [[extremism]] and [[terrorism]].{{Cite web|url=http://asozd2.duma.gov.ru/main.nsf/%28SpravkaNew%29?OpenAgent&RN=1039149-6&02|title=Законопроект № 1039149-6|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=10 August 2016}} On 13 May 2016, the act passed after the first reading.{{Cite web|url=http://vote.duma.gov.ru/vote/94599|title=(первое чтение) О проекте федерального закона № 1039101-6 "О внесении изменений в Уголовный кодекс Российской Федерации и Уголовно-процессуальный кодекс Российской Федерации в части установления дополнительных мер противодействия терроризму и обеспечения общественной безопасности" – Система анализа результатов голосований на заседаниях Государственной Думы|last=|first=|date=|website=vote.duma.gov.ru|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=2016-08-10}} Prior to that, it had received support from the [[Dmitry Medvedev's First Cabinet|prime minister's cabinet]]. On 7 July it was signed by the [[President of Russia]], [[Vladimir Putin]]. Most of the act's amendments came into effect on 20 July 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://rusbase.com/opinion/yarovaya-pack/|title=Под закон Яровой подпадают все облачные сервисы и интернет-магазины {{!}} Rusbase|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=2016-08-10}} Amendments that require telecom operators to [[Telecommunications data retention|store]] recordings of phone conversations, text messages and users' internet traffic up to 6 months were announced to come into place on 1 July 2018; however, senator Anton Belyakov has submitted a proposal to move the regulations' start date to 2023, because of the extreme amount of [[Computer data storage|data storage technology]] needed to make fulfilling the requirements possible.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/19jul2016/antiyarovaya.html|title=В Совете Федерации предложили перенести вступление в силу "пакета Яровой" на 2023 год|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=2016-08-10}} == Content == === Penal provisions === The amendments of the Yarovaya law include lengthening of prison terms for a number of criminal activities, introduction of new reasons to deny entry or departure to and from [[Russia]], and the introduction of criminal liability for failure to report to law enforcement authorities that someone else "has been planning, is perpetrating, or has perpetrated" terrorist activity.{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/06/23/draconian-law-rammed-through-russian-parliament|title=Draconian Law Rammed Through Russian Parliament|last=|first=|date=2016-06-23|website=Human Rights Watch|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-10}}{{Cite news|url=http://kommersant.ru/doc/2984588|title=Борьбу Ирины Яровой с терроризмом подвергли критике|last=Самохина|first=Софья|date=|work=|access-date=2016-08-10|last2=Самохина|first2=Софья|issue=82|pages=3|language=Russian|via=|newspaper=Газета "Коммерсантъ"}} ===Surveillance provisions=== The Yarovaya amendments require telecom providers to store the content of voice calls, data, images and text messages for 6 months, and the [[metadata]] on them (e.g. time, location, and sender and recipients of messages) for 3 years. Online services such as messaging services, email and social networks that use encrypted data are required to permit the [[Federal Security Service]] (FSB) to access and read their encrypted communications.{{Cite news|url=http://www.interfax.ru/russia/519643|title=ФСБ избавила мессенджеры от сертификации средств шифрования по "закону Яровой"|date=2016-07-20|work=Interfax.ru|access-date=2017-07-20|language=ru-RU}} Internet and telecom companies are required to disclose these communications and metadata, as well as "all other information necessary" to authorities on request and without a court order.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/07/12/russia-big-brother-law-harms-security-rights|title=Russia: ‘Big Brother’ Law Harms Security, Rights|date=2016-07-12|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-07-02|language=en}} ===Anti-evangelism provisions=== The amendments also include new restrictions on [[evangelism]] and [[missionary work]].{{cite web|title=Thousands Fasting After Russian President Putin Signs Law Banning Evangelism Outside of Churches|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/thousands-fasting-after-russian-president-putin-signs-law-banning-evangelism-outside-of-churches-166345/|website=Christian Post|accessdate=18 September 2016}} The amendments add a new provision to Russia's Religion Legislation, stating that "missionary activity" may only be performed "without hindrance" at churches and other religious sites designated by the chapter. It is explicitly banned from residential buildings. "Missionary activity" is defined as
The activity of a religious association, aimed at disseminating information about its [[Religious belief|beliefs]] among [[Non-believer|people who are not participants (members, followers) in that religious association]], with the purpose of involving these people as participants (members, followers). It is carried out directly by religious associations or by citizens and/or legal entities authorised by them, publicly, with the help of the media, the internet or other lawful means".{{cite web|title=RUSSIA: Putin signs sharing beliefs, "extremism", punishments|url=http://forum18.org/archive.php?article_id=2197|website=[[Forum 18]]|accessdate=18 September 2016}}
Missionary activities may not be used to pursue violations of public safety, "the motivation of citizens to refuse to fulfil their civic duties as established by law and to commit other illegal acts", [[suicide]], or the refusal of medical treatment on religious grounds as aims. Missionary activities may only be performed by authorized members of registered religious groups and organizations. A group becomes ineligible to perform missionary activities if they have been banned under a court order for practicing extremism or terrorism, or have been liquidated. Foreign missionaries may only perform missionary activities after registering for a permit from a recognized religious organization.{{cite web|title=Russia's Ban on Evangelism Is Now in Effect|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/july/russia-ban-evangelism-effect.html|website=Christianity Today|accessdate=17 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Russia's new 'big brother law' has Christians, Muslims and Jews fearing for their religious freedom|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865657712/Russias-new-big-brother-law-has-Christians-Muslims-and-Jews-fearing-for-their-religious-freedom.html?pg=all|website=Deseret News|accessdate=17 September 2016}} Citizens are also required to report unauthorized religious activity to the government or face fines. == Implementation == ===Surveillance provisions=== Because of unprecedented data storage requirements, implementation of the law has been described as impossible and extremely expensive.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/opinion/articles/2016/06/29/647156-prava-grazhdan|title=Дорогой, неэффективный, нарушающий права граждан|last=|first=|date=2016-06-28|website=Vedomosti|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=2016-08-10}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/07/russia-asks-impossible-its-new-surveillance-laws|title=Russia Asks For The Impossible With Its New Surveillance Laws|date=2016-07-19|access-date=2016-08-10}} The [[Russian Post]] estimated that the implementation of the law would cost the organization 500 billion [[ruble]]s for initial purchases of equipment and 100 billion rubles yearly.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rbc.ru/technology_and_media/08/07/2016/577f82279a79478ad1ed4f96|title="Почта России" оценила исполнение "закона Яровой" в полтриллиона рублей|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=Russian|access-date=2016-08-10}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.ru/news/324549-pochte-rossii-pridetsya-potratit-500-mlrd-rublei-na-ispolnenie-zakona-yarovoi|title="Почте России" придется потратить 500 млрд рублей на исполнение "закона Яровой"|website=www.forbes.ru|access-date=2016-08-10}} Implementation of the law by other delivery and freight services was estimated to cost around 180 billion rubles, which is projected to cause 30–40% drop in online number of purchases.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/business/articles/2016/07/13/648971-zakon-yarovoi-logisticheskim|title=Закон Яровой может стоить логистическим компаниям 180 млрд рублей|date=2016-07-12|access-date=2016-08-10}} Cell service operators will need 2.2 trillion rubles to comply, which will cause a two- or threefold rise in the cost of mobile services for the consumer. Edward Snowden estimated the combined cost of implementation to be 33 billion dollars and predicted that the overall security levels will be unaffected, despite giant affiliated costs.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-07/putin-s-anti-terror-law-sends-telecommunications-companies-lower|title=Putin’s ‘Big Brother’ Surveillance Law Criticized by Snowden|last=Khrennikov|first=Ilya|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-08-10}} After Putin signed the law, it turned out that equipment that is needed to store all the data is non-existent not only in Russia, but in the world. Because of that Putin has issued a call for government contracts to Russian companies for the required hardware and software.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/14jul2016/zakonyarovoy.html|title=Достаточного количества оборудования для исполнения "закона Яровой" нет даже за рубежом, сообщили в МЭР|access-date=2016-08-10}} ===Anti-evangelism provisions=== A number of missionaries have been subject to arrest for violating the law and, upon conviction, have been fined. Donald and Ruth Ossewaarde, independent missionaries working in [[Oryol]], were fined 40,000 rubles (around $700), prompting the couple to leave the country; Sergei Zhuravlyov, a Ukrainian Reformed Orthodox Church of Christ representative, was arrested for engaging in preaching in [[St. Petersburg]]; and Ebenezer Tuah of [[Ghana]], the leader of the Christ Embassy church, was arrested and fined 50,000 rubles for conducting baptisms at a [[sanatorium]].Mark Woods, [http://www.christiantoday.com/article/us.missionarys.work.ended.by.russias.anti.evangelism.law/94482.htm US missionary's work ended by Russia's anti-evangelism law], ''Christian Today'' (September 2, 2016). On 9 July 2016, Jim Mulcahy, a 72-year-old American pastor who is the Eastern European coordinator for the U.S.-based [[Metropolitan Community Church]], was arrested and deported under the prohibition of missionary activities at non-religious sites, after advertising and holding a "tea party" in [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] with an LGBT group. Authorities had targeted Mulcahy under suspicions that he was planning to organize a [[Same-sex marriage in Russia|same-sex wedding]].{{cite web|title=Russia's Newest Law: No Evangelizing Outside of Church|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2016/june/no-evangelizing-outside-of-church-russia-proposes.html|website=Christianity Today|accessdate=17 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Zavadski|first1=Katie|title=Russia Was So Afraid of Gay Marriage, It Kicked Out This Priest|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/07/31/russia-was-so-afraid-of-gay-marriage-it-kicked-out-this-priest.html|website=The Daily Beast|accessdate=17 September 2016}}{{cite news|author=Levi Bridges |title= American pastor expelled from Russia in LGBT case|newspaper=Washington Post|date=26 July 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/american-pastor-expelled-from-russia-in-lgbt-case/2016/07/26/9b8ac09c-531e-11e6-b652-315ae5d4d4dd_story.html}} == Criticism and protests == Russia's largest [[telecommunication]] and internet companies expressed their concerns regarding the negative impacts of the law on their businesses and on the Russian economy on the whole. A [[Change.org]] petition to completely cancel Yarovaya's Act collected over 600,000 signatures.{{Cite web|url=http://www.macdigger.ru/macall/peticiyu-protiv-zakona-yarovoj-podpisali-500-000-chelovek.html|title=Петицию против "закона Яровой" за четыре дня подписали 500 000 человек {{!}} MacDigger.ru – новости из мира Apple|website=www.macdigger.ru|access-date=2016-08-10}} Russian Public Initiative petition has been signed more than 100,000 times.{{Cite web|url=https://www.roi.ru/28432/|title=РОИ :: Отменить "закон Яровой"|website=www.roi.ru|access-date=2016-08-10}} A number of protests were organized in cities, including in [[Novosibirsk]], [[Yekaterinburg]], [[Ufa]], [[Kazan]] and [[Volgograd]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/26jul2016/mitings.html|title=В российских городах прошли акции против антитеррористического "пакета Яровой"|access-date=2016-08-10}} A 9 August protest in [[Moscow]] has seen over 2,000 participants.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/09aug2016/yarovayamiting.html|title=В Москве на митинг против "пакета Яровой" пришли около двух тысяч человек|access-date=2016-08-10}} ===Criticisms of anti-evangelism provisions=== The anti-evangelism provisions of the legislation prompted an outcry of concern and opposition from [[Protestantism in Russia|Russia's Protestant minority]], which makes up about 1% of Russia's population. According to experts, the law is likely to be interpreted in a way so as to block churches other than the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] evangelizing to [[ethnic Russians]]. Religious denominations with a smaller presence in Russia have long been viewed with hostility from government officials and Russian Orthodox religious authorities.The harsh new restrictions on minority religious groups were in addition to already-existing requirements under a 1997 law that mandated registration and administrative procedures which many religious groups found onerous and expensive to comply with.{{cite web|title=Russia's 'Yarovaya Law' Imposes Harsh New Restrictions On Religious Groups|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/russia-yarovaya-law-religious-freedom-restrictions/27852531.html|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|accessdate=21 March 2017}} [[Thomas J. Reese]], the chair of the [[U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom]], said that "Neither these measures nor the currently existing anti-extremism law meet international human rights and religious freedom standards" and that the Yarovaya Law "will make it easier for Russian authorities to repress religious communities, stifle peaceful dissent, and detain and imprison people."{{cite press release|title=RUSSIA: USCIRF Condemns Enactment of Anti-Terrorism Laws|url=http://www.uscirf.gov/news-room/press-releases/russia-uscirf-condemns-enactment-anti-terrorism-laws|publisher=United States Commission on International Religious Freedom|accessdate=21 March 2017}} Faith McDonnell of the [[Institute on Religion and Democracy]] in Washington, D.C., said: "The law doesn't do that much to defend from terrorism and only prevents Christians and others who are not [Russian] Orthodox from preaching and proselytizing."{{cite web|author=Fred Lucas|title=Back to the Soviet Era’: Putin’s New Law Could Lead to Religious Crackdown|url=http://dailysignal.com/2016/07/20/back-to-the-soviet-era-putins-new-law-could-lead-to-religious-crackdown/|website=The Daily Signal|publisher=The Heritage Foundation|date=July 20, 2016}} U.S. State Department spokeswoman Nicole Thompson wrote that: "We believe that these new amendments will not better protect Russia’s citizens, but are rather part of a troubling Russian trend of intimidation and harassment of civil society and political activists." The law exempts the government-allied [[Moscow Patriarchate]] of the Russian Orthodox Church from the measures that it applies to all other religious groups. The [[Russian Orthodox Autonomous Church|autonomous Russian Orthodox Church]] opposed the law; Archbishop Andrew Maklakov, administrator of the Russian Orthodox Autonomous Church of America, stated: "As the Russian Federation has drifted back to its Soviet roots more and more over the past 25 years, it has increasingly sought to harass, persecute, and destroy any religious organization that it might consider competition to its own 'state church.'" ===Criticisms of expanded surveillance provisions=== The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], a nonprofit group that aims to defend civil liberties in the digital world, opposed the Yarovaya package, noting that "opposition to the Yarovaya package has come from many quarters. Technical experts have been united in opposing the law. Russia’s government Internet ombudsman opposed the bill. Putin's own human rights head, Mikhail Fedotov, called upon the Senators of Russia’s Federal Council to reject the bill. ISPs have pointed out that compliance would cost them trillions of rubles."{{cite web|authors=[[Eva Galperin]] & Danny O'Brien|title=Russia Asks For The Impossible With Its New Surveillance Laws|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/07/russia-asks-impossible-its-new-surveillance-laws|publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation|date=July 19, 2016}} The EFF wrote that because Russia's ISPs, messaging services, and social media platforms "cannot reasonably comply with all the demands of the Yarovaya package, they become de facto criminals whatever their actions. And that, in turn, gives the Russian state the leverage to extract from them any other concession it desires. The impossibility of full compliance is not a bug—it's an essential feature." [[Human Rights Watch]] noted the lack of judicial oversight and stated that "these provisions would ultimately jeopardize security, while being ineffective at preventing terrorists from using encryption" as well as "unjustifiably expand surveillance while undermining human rights and cybersecurity." == See also == * [[Mass surveillance in Russia]] * [[SORM]] == References == {{Reflist|3}}
